definitions.definition: to move to or towards a person or place

examples.text: He left and said he was never coming back.
He came into the room and shut the door.
She comes to work by bus.
My son is **coming home** soon.
**Come here**!
Come and see us soon!
**Here comes** Jo! *(= Jo is coming)*
There's a storm coming.
They're coming to stay for a week.
He came towards me.
I hope you can come to Australia to visit us.
It's looks as if there's a storm coming.
When is your son coming home?

definitions.definition: to arrive at or reach a place

examples.text: They continued until they came to a river.
She came to work wearing a very smart suit.
They came as far as the gate.
People came from all over the country.
Your breakfast is coming soon.
Have any letters come for me?
Help came at last.
What time did you come (= to my house)?
People came from all over the world to settle here.
Let me know if any more mail comes.
He came to England by ship.
If you come late, the doctor may not be able to see you.

definitions.definition: to arrive somewhere in order to do something or get something
definitions.sensetop: come for somethingcome about somethingcome to do somethingcome doing something

examples.text: I've come for my book.
I've come about my book.
I've come to get my book.
He came looking for me.
I've come for those books you promised me.
I've come to see Mrs Cooper.

definitions.definition: to move or travel, especially with somebody else, to a particular place or in order to be present at an event
definitions.sensetop: come to do somethingcome to somethingcome to something with somebodycome with somebodycome doing something

examples.text: I've only come for an hour.
Thanks for coming *(= to my house, party, etc.)*.
Ten thousand people came to hear him speak.
Are you coming to the lecture?
Are you coming to the club with us tonight?
Come with me—I've got something to show you.
Why don't you come skating tonight?
Please come to my party on September 10th.
Are you coming to the theatre with us this evening?
I'm sorry, I won't be able to come.
Despite all the publicity, not many people came.
If you can't come to the meeting, let us know in advance.

definitions.definition: to travel a particular distance

examples.text: We've come 50 miles this morning.
The company has **come a long way** *(= made lot of progress)* in the last 5 years.
He's come all the way from Tokyo.
We've come a long way and we're very tired.
How far have you come?

definitions.definition: to move in a particular way or while doing something else
definitions.sensetop: come doing something + adv./prep.come doing something

examples.text: A car came flying round the corner.
A huge wave came crashing over the sea wall.
Questions came rushing into her head.
Don't expect me to **come running **every time you call.
The children came running into the room.
A crowd of men on horses carrying spears came charging down the road.

definitions.definition: to happen

examples.text: The agreement came after several hours of negotiations.
The rains came too late to do any good.
Spring came late this year.
**The time has come ***(= now is the moment)* to act.
His first goal came in the 81st minute.
His resignation **came as no surprise**.
Her death **came as a** terrible **shock** to us.
More details of the event are **coming soon**.
Dusk came quickly.
I never thought the day would come when I'd feel sorry for him.
The deadline came and went, but there was no reply from them.
Business improved as Christmas came nearer.
At last, the time came to leave.
When the moment actually came, I began to feel a little nervous.
He wanted to be buried beside her when the time came.
The time had come to let a younger person lead the party.
The high point of the concert came during the drum solo.

definitions.definition: used in questions to talk about how or why something happened

examples.text: How did he come to break his leg?
How do you come to be so late?

definitions.definition: to have a particular position

examples.text: That comes a long way down my list of priorities.
She **came second** *(= received the second highest score)* in the exam.
His family **comes first** *(= is the most important thing in his life)*.

definitions.definition: used in many expressions to show that something has reached a particular state

examples.text: At last winter **came to an end**.
He **came to power** in 2019.
We need to **come to an agreement** on this issue.
When will they **come to a decision**?
our understanding of how the universe **came into existence**
The trees are coming into leaf.

definitions.definition: to be available or to exist in a particular way
definitions.sensetop: come in somethingcome with something+ adj.

examples.text: This dress comes in black and red.
The new edition of the game comes with a whole range of upgrades.
New cars don't **come cheap** *(= they are expensive)*.
This luxury villa **comes complete with** its own private swimming pool.

definitions.definition: to become

examples.text: The handle came loose.
The buttons had come undone.
Everything will **come right** in the end.
the Nigerian film industry, which came to be known as Nollywood

definitions.definition: to reach a point where you realize, understand or believe something

examples.text: In time she came to love him.
She had come to see the problem in a new light.
I've come to expect this kind of behaviour from him.

definitions.definition: to have an orgasm
to be very clever, stupid, etc.
to play the part of a particular type of person; to behave in a particular way

examples.text: Don't come the innocent with me.

definitions.definition: used to ask somebody to repeat something

examples.text: ‘She's an entomologist.’ ‘Come again?’ ‘An entomologist—she studies insects.’

definitions.definition: to arrive and leave; to move freely

examples.text: They had a party next door—we heard people **coming and going** all night.

definitions.definition: to be present for a short time and then go away

examples.text: The pain in my leg comes and goes.

definitions.definition: to be easy, natural, etc. for somebody to do

examples.text: Acting comes naturally to her.

definitions.definition: to be unsuccessful; to have no successful result

examples.text: How sad that all his hard work should come to nothing.
Her plans didn't come to anything.

definitions.definition: used to introduce something extra that is connected with what has just been said

examples.text: I don't really trust him—or his wife, come to that.

definitions.definition: despite any problems or difficulties you may have

examples.text: He promised to support her come what may.

definitions.definition: used to say you do not understand how something can happen and would like an explanation

examples.text: ‘I think you owe me some money.’ ‘How come?’
If she spent five years in Paris, how come her French is so bad?

definitions.definition: to not be important or successful
in the future

examples.text: They may well regret the decision **in years to come**.
This will be a problem **for some time to come** *(= for a period of time in the future)*.

definitions.definition: when it is a question of something

examples.text: When it comes to getting things done, he's useless.

definitions.definition: somebody’s ideas, beliefs, personality, etc. that makes them say what they have said

examples.text: I see where you're coming from *(= I understand what you mean)*.

wordOrigin: Old English cuman, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch komen and German kommen.
